While the relationship between Trump and Un has been significantly positive (Un going so far as to recently issue a statement wishing Trump well in his bout with COVID) (1) and the North Koreans certainly enjoy the optic value of Un meeting with Trump, I think given the ongoing COVID situation and the U.S. political climate it is unlikely that such a meeting will occur prior to the new year. First, while North Korea has declared it has no COIVD infections, this claim is almost virtually guaranteed to be false; given the country’s underdeveloped medical infrastructure and proximity to China the nation likely has been hit very hard by the disease, accordingly, Trump is very unlikely to travel near a COVID hotspot. (2) Second, North Korea has not launched a missile since 2017, (3) while the DRPK remains an omnipresent foreign policy challenge for the United States, given the nation’s recent good behavior and the current American fixation on domestic politics (RE COVID and race relations) barring renewed agitation by the North Koreans Trump has little incentive to engage Un further in the near future. References 
1. Norman, Sam, 2020. “North Korea's Kim Jong Un offers sympathies to Trump, first lady after COVID-19 diagnoses”, Fox News. Retrieved from https://www.foxnews.com/world/north-korea-kim-jong-un-sympathies-trump-covid
2. The Economist, 2020 “North Korea is lonelier than ever” Retrieved from https://www.economist.com/asia/2020/10/24/north-korea-is-lonelier-than-ever
3. Nuclear Threat Initiative Project. “The CNS North Korea Missile Test Database”, 2020, https://www.nti.org/analysis/articles/cns-north-korea-missile-test-database/

In forecasting whether Trump and Kim will meet in 2020, I will assume that it will be held outside the United States like their previous meetings.  In 2020 Trump will be seeking reelection as President. Looking at the international trips the previous 5 Presidents (Obama-Reagan) made during their reelection year ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_trips_made_by_presidents_of_the_United_States   The international trips these Presidents made from September 3rd-December 31st were ->
Obama-2012 1 trips, Bush-2004 2 trips, Clinton-1996 1 trips, Bush-1992 1 trips, Reagan-1984 0 trips. Average international trips made by President in their reelection year from 3/9 - 31/12 = 1 = (1 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 0) / 5 Of the 19 international trips Trump has made so far as President, he has met Kim on 3 of them ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_presidential_trips_made_by_Donald_Trump   Trump-Kim meeting in 2020 = 16% = 1 * (3 / 19) Given Trump has made 19 vs 24 trips compared to Obama at this stage in his 1st term, the last trip being in February and the presence of the COVID-19 global pandemic I will reduce the probability of a Trump-Kim meeting ->
Trump-Kim meeting in 2020 = 8% = 16% * 0.5

Chance of an unprovoked visit: Established a base rate of number of foreign trips made in the final year of a first term of presidency from [1], at 9. This takes into account the % of the average trips made by that president, given it is their final year, to determine the effect of the electoral campaign on amount of countries visited.
Trumps average is 12 per year so far.[2]  
On average presidents visited around 75% of their usual average on election year, so put it at 9 for this year.
There is some uncertainty with this statistic given the small amount of data used (only used the last 6 presidents) There is 1/3 of the year left so downgraded it to around 3 countries most likely.
Realistically the pool of countries he could visit is at around 50. This gives a 6% chance of visiting any particular country, not taking into account COVID.
COVID means travelling internationally to meet people looks bad in terms of commitment to public health, and is undesirable for the leaders themselves. Reduces likelihood to 1/3 = 2%
North Korea have also said they do not want a meeting. This means that even if trump wanted a meeting and could do a meeting, 40% chance NK would actually accept.
=0.8% Chance of provoked visit: 1.2% chance for a NK crisis based on the number of crises in the last 20 years and the number of times a president has responded by visiting NK for a summit. [3] Essentially this is an upwards adjustment due to the volatility of NK.
There will be a lesser COVID effect here if the situation is more urgent, maybe 3/4 the likelihood of visiting = +0.9% = 1.7% Any comments welcome. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_trips_made_by_presidents_of_the_United_States [1]
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_presidential_trips_made_by_Donald_Trump [2]
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Korea#21st_century [3]

Outside: typical protocol for restarting negotiations like this seems to be in-person meetings by subordinates (such as sec state) prior to direct head of state talks. That would affect the timeline. Obviously, whether or not trump is reelected would have major effects on the probability of this event. Overall, in-person meetings between US officials and leaders of countries with which we do not maintain normal diplomatic relations are extremely rare. Inside: I could envision Trump agreeing to a meeting with KJU in the run-up to the election if doing so would enable a coherent PR win, such as if North Korea signaled their intent to agree to some sort of concession. This seems to me unlikely. Similarly, I have trouble envisioning a scenario in which Trump wins the election and immediately begins to re-prioritize the negotiations with KJU to a degree that facilitates a meeting in the short time before the new year. Again, it seems like a post election meeting would need to rely on initiation by North Korea, which I view as unlikely. I also think the ongoing domestic issues related to COVID-19 will further distract whatever administration is in place post-election and reduces the probability of any high-level diplomatic engagement. Forecast: The probability of an in-person meeting is extremely low.

On June 12, 2020, the two-year anniversary of the Singapore summit, the North Korean Minister of Foreign Affairs released a press statement that the Trump administration efforts in the past two years were for political achievements without returns for North Korea and "Nothing is more hypocritical than an empty promise." North Korea subsequently cut communications with South Korea, demolished the four-story joint-liaison office building it shared with South Korea on June 17, and ceased efforts for diplomatic relations with the United States. (https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/north-korea-s-kim-backs-away-trump-relationship-two-years-n1230371) Donald Trump has long-since lost his shine for the idea of being the statesman who single-handedly leads to peace on the Korean Peninsula after realising it required more than a one-off photo op. With his attention now almost entirely focussed on personal and political priorities (avoiding prison, securing another term in office and mitigating the damage of Covid-19, in that order) it is almost certain that he will not be meeting Kim Jong-Un in the forseeable future, even if Coronavirus travel restrictions were to be lifted any time soon.

(Note that I am considering the question to be referring to an in-person, bilateral meeting rather than the two bumping into each other at the UN urinals. The wording  of the question could be clearer.) Factors considered:
- historical precedent;
- possible new triggers;
- potential obstacles to a meeting. HISTORICAL PRECEDENT
North Korea (NK) has a dependence on foreign aid, and using belligerence to gain more of that aid (citation needed). This belligerence has only once resulted in a meeting between the US President and the Supreme Leader, following the 2017-18 North Korea Crisis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_North_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_Singapore_Summit#Background). A number of factors created these conditions so calculating the likelihood of a similar "fever pitch" will obviously be difficult. For simplicity's sake, let's say that the necessary precipitating conditions are regular increased long-range nuclear payload delivery testing and increased sanctions on NK by the US. 
- As of the date of writing, NK has conducted a test of 2 unidentified projectiles on 2 March 2020, with the next most recent test being short range projectiles on 28 November 2019. There has been no 'streak' of long range ballistic missile tests since 2017. Very roughly, this puts the per year rate of NK increased long-range nuclear payload delivery testing at 1/3 or 0.333 (sampling only the Trump presidency).
- The US has increased sanctions on North Korea multiple times during the Trump presidency, though all during 2017. As some of these were arguably in response to NK belligerence, we will increase the likelihood slightly to account for the potential of low level NK belligerence prompting a further increase. 0.400
- I am not accounting for the feedback loop of one of these conditions increasing the likelihood of the other, as I don't know how to do that. The likelihood of both occurring, and thus the historical likelihood of conditions precipitating the to leaders meeting is therefore 0.333 * 0.400 = 0.133 POSSIBLE ALTERNATIVE PRECIPITATION
COVID-19 stresses could drive NK to seek additional aid by diplomatic or other means. I will assume more provocative means are preferred due to that being NK's MO and producing results faster. I would say 0.430 given the already precipitous relationship NK has with stability.  LIKELY OBSTACLES
I do not see any likely obstacles, particularly not COVID-19 social distancing norms. NK's leadership will not want to be seen as fearing the virus, and the US President will want to encourage the opening of America and return to normality. There is a possibility that the conditions in the US would require the president's attention to the extent he has to neglect foreign affairs, but I would peg that as 0.01 or smaller. Let's say 0.01 to account for uncertainty. RESULT
Our model is therefore:  ( likelihood of precipitation conditions + likelihood of alternative triggers ) - probability of potential obstacles  thus ( 0.133 + 0.430 ) - 0.01 = 0.553 55% Chance

The US and north Korea have been trying to plan a second summit between the leaders of the two countries since the first summit occurred. However, multiple incidents have occurred since that first meeting that has not allowed a second summit to occur. Specifically, on 10 Feb 2020, President Donald J Trump reportedly told advisors that he did not want a second summit before the November elections [1]. Additionally, the US government is planning for the COVID-19 pandemic to last up to 18 months [2] and the US and on 19 March 2020 the US State Department issued a level 4 travel advisory, which advises all Americans not to travel abroad [3]. Further, China is north Korea's largest supporter and trade partner [4]. north Korea has claimed that not a single resident has been infected by COVID-19, however, there are multiple signs that the country is suffering from a massive outbreak [5]. Additionally, China has asked the US to resume negotiations with north Korea and lessen sanctions in order to assist north Korea with combating COVID-19 infections [6]. However, President Donald J. Trump continues to call the COVID-19 pandemic the "Chinese Virus"[7] and will most likely avoid doing anything that could provide positive press to China. Additionally, if the COVID-19 outbreak continues into the fall, north Korea might refuse to meet with the US delegation in order to avoid publicizing any impact the pandemic has had on their country. Finally, President Donald J Trump will most likely want to focus on domestic issues leading up to the November election, especially since the stock market has fallen back to the same levels it was at when he was elected to office [8]. If he focused his efforts and planning on meeting with a foreign leader, especially one that is a dictator and adversary of the US, instead of focusing on ways to help the US recover, it would likely poll poorly amongst swing voters. If he wins the Presidential election in November, he will be more focused on core issues that are more important to his base than north Korea (i.e. illegal immigration, stock market gains, helping the US economy recover from the effects of COVID-19). Thus, I assess a 0% possibility that President Donald J. Trump will meet with kim jong un before 1 January 2020. [1] https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/10/politics/trump-north-korea-thaw/index.html
